Description: This type of reliquary, sometimes called bursa or "purse-shaped," originated in Germany and Austria in the 13th century. On the back is a long inscription that lists all the relics once contained inside. In the Middle Ages, it was not unusual to combine many relics in one container, thereby increasing the number of saints who could potentially intercede to help answer the prayers of the faithful.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: The Art of Empathy: The Cummer Mother of Sorrows in Context
Exhibitions.Textblock: The Art of Empathy: The Cummer Mother of Sorrows in Context. The Cummer Museum of Art and Gardens, Jacksonville. 2013-2014.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Reliquaries and Ritual: Medieval Objects of Devotion
Exhibitions.Textblock: Reliquaries and Ritual: Medieval Objects of Devotion. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1984-1985.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Zeit der Frühen Habsburger: Dome und Klöster, 1279-1379
Exhibitions.Textblock: Zeit der Frühen Habsburger: Dome und Klöster, 1279-1379. Stift Klosterneuburg, Klosterneuburg. 1979.

Inscriptions: [Transcription] Inscribed on one long side panel of the reliquary: +DE.DENTE.S.BARTHOL.S. / PETRI.ET.PAVLI.THOME.ST / EPHI.PANTAL.M.ET.D'CAPUTE / XPOFORI.M.VNDECI.M.V.D.SE / PL'CRO.D.BNDCI.ABB'D'PSEPE. / D'.DE.CAPILL'.S.M.VIRG.DE. / VESTE.CORNELII.ET.ALIOR.SCR;  [Translation] Inscribed on one long side panel of the reliquary: of the tooth of St. Bartholomew, Sts. Peter and Paul, Thomas, Stephen, Pantaleon, martyrs; and of the head of Christopher, martyr; the Eleven Thousand Virgins; of the sepulcher of the Lord; of Benedict, Abbot; of the cradle of the Lord; of the hair of the Blessed Virgin Mary; of the garment of Cornelius and of other saints.
Medium: gilt copper set with mother of pearl, rubies or spinels, rock crystal, turquoise, and unidentified gem stones
Provenance: Ernest Odiot, Paris; Sale, Chevalier & Mannheim, Paris, April 26-27, 1889, no. 62; Chabrières-Arles, Paris [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Joseph Duveen, London [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henri Daguerre, Paris [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1922, by purchase; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Reliquary of the Virgin and Saints
